bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Felipe Ponce Carbonell, November 4, 1952

div1.p: Hench is concerned that the Camp Lazear memorial will be named for Finlay rather than Lazear. He requests that Carbonell discreetly contact Nogueira about the matter.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Felipe Ponce Carbonell, November 4, 1952
div1.opener:
November 4, 1952
Dr. Felipe Carbonell
San Lazaro 413
Havana, Cuba
My dear Doctor Carbonell:
div1.p:
Have there been any notices in the Havana newspapers during the last three
or four months concerning the impending dedication of Camp Lazear? This
summer, Dr. Pedro Nogueira and his associates suddenly got busy and completed
their plans for making Camp Lazear into a park, erecting a wall on which will
appear certain bronze tablets and medallions, erecting a flag pole, building
a road and putting in some landscaping. I have had some correspondence with
Doctor Nogueira this summer and I have been informed that the dedication is
set for December 3, the date of Finlay's birthday or “Physicians' Day” in
Cuba.

Earlier this spring, I was rather concerned because when I received from
Doctor Nogueira a blue print of the proposed plan, Walter Reed's Building No. 1
was labelled “Caseta de Finlay.” Although he assured me this was an error,
a number of clippings from Havana papers which were sent to me by various
friends in Havana, perpetuated that error and wrote as though it were Doctor
Finlay who had done the work. Please see the enclosed.

Doctor Nogueira has assured me that the caseta will not be named after Doctor
Finlay. It was my hope that the camp should be rededicated as “Camp Lazear”
but I fear that it will be called “Parque Finlay.” Now Doctor Nogueira has
assured me that justice and fairness will be afforded to Major Reed and his
American associates and I must believe him. Nevertheless, I am writing to
you to ask if it would be possible for you, diplomatically and very dis-
cretely, to get in touch with Doctor Nogueira and ask him about the plans.
Camp Lazear is a most appropriate place in which to erect a memorial to all
those concerned with the conquest of yellow fever, in particular Doctor
Finlay as well as Major Reed because actually it was the caseta of the Finca
San Jose (the same Finca San Jose where later Camp Lazear was erected) where
Finlay himself did two or three of his early experiments. Therefore, it is
most appropriate that this place be dedicated primarily to Doctor Finlay,
Major Reed, Doctor Lazear and their associates.

I am placed in a rather delicate situation. I know it will disappoint certain
people if Camp Lazear is not allowed to retain its name, but I have done all
I can properly do. Would you be able to see Doctor Nogueira and would you
be inclined to do so without letting on that I prompted you to do so? Would
it be possible for you to approach him, merely saying that you had seen the
former newspaper clippings and that you had heard of the impending dedication
and since you have been so interested in the project for years, you were anxious
to know something more about it and whether you could help in any way.

I have been informed by Doctor Nogueira that the Cuban Government plans to of-
ficially invite certain Americans, such as the Surgeon General or his deputy
and so on, to attend the ceremony and I myself am making plans to fly down for
it. However no official invitations, I believe, have been sent out as yet.

I do hope that this affair can be made the occasion for a demonstration of
Cuban-American friendship, especially a friendship between Cuban and American
physicians. I shall appreciate your reaction to the proposed plans and I
hope that the plans of those in charge will satisfy you and the rest of us
who have been so anxious to have this Camp dedication.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
Enclosure
P.S.: To remind you of the significance of Camp Lazear, of Reed's little
building and also of the rediscovery of the camp, permit me to send the
enclosed reprint. The rediscovery is described on pages 3 through 7.
